Questions.QuestionText: It’s known for vibrant fall foliage and being a symbol of Canada.
This tree is known for its tall, unbranched trunk and large, fan-like leaves. They’re planted in rows to farm oil in Southeast Asia.
This coastal tree thrives in salty water, often developing exposed roots that help stabilize shorelines and provide habitats for marine life.
Known for its gracefully drooping branches and often found near water, this tree’s flexible twigs have been used for basket weaving for centuries.
Known for its striking white bark that peels in thin layers, this tree is common in northern forests.
This tree is recognizable by its flat-topped canopy and small, feathery leaves, and is famous for surviving harsh, dry climates.
Often found in the American South, this tee is known for its large, fragrant white flowers and glossy leaves.
A part of the rose family, the Sakura tree is one of its varieties, known for stunning, short-lived spring flowers.
Native to the Mediterranean, this tree is prized for its small, oval fruit and for its long lifespan.
Unlike most conifers, this tree is deciduous, shedding its needles in autumn. There are Siberian, European and Subalpine varieties.
